messageBody:
Robert Sartin wrote:
> Why is
> reporting more
> than one such assertion failure not more useful than only
> reporting the
> first? How is reporting two assertion failures different from a test
> that manages to pack multiple booleans into a single assertTrue and
> pass back the extra failure information in the message?

The main problem I have with continuing after a failure is that you may get
multiple chained failures.

Here is a simple example, for retrieving a value from a Map:

public void testRetrieve() {
// there's already a declared Map instance called test.
assertNull(test.get("TestKey"));
test.put("TestKey", "This is a test value");
Object retrievedValue = test.get("TestKey"));
assertNull(retrievedValue);
assert(retrievedValue instanceof String);
assertEquals("This is a test value", retrievedValue);
}

If the Map was broken (say, it always returned a value for "TestKey"),
there's no point continuing with the rest of the test.

Obtaining multiple information on failures is already possible in the
framework; simply extract unrelated tests out to seperate test methods.
Pretty much by defintion, if a failure of an assert won't trigger multiple
other failures, then you've got unrelated tests.

Robert.
